attributes.title: Alabama Special Senate Election Canvassing Study

q1.value: Alabama Special Senate Election Canvassing Study

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: The Doug Jones for Senate campaign conducts a block-randomized field experiment with 8,180 female Republican voters in the Birmingham, Alabama, suburbs, assigned either to control or one of two treatment conditions. In both treatment options, subjects discuss the position of the opposing candidate, Roy Moore, on women’s issues, including the right to vote and pursue public office. In one treatment, subjects speak with a female canvasser at their doorstep, and in the other, subjects speak with women over the phone. After the election, the researchers conduct a telephone survey to test whether contact with the campaign affected attitudes and vote choice, and obtain data from the public register to test whether it increased turnout for Doug Jones or dampened support for Roy Moore. Moreover, they test how the treatment indirectly affected the spouses of female voters who were contacted by the campaign.

q16.value: Direct effects (two-tailed tests) Persuasion hypotheses: H1a. Women assigned to canvass/phone call are less likely to think that Roy Moore is supportive of a women’s role in public life than women assigned to the control group. H1b. Women assigned to canvass/phone call are more likely to vote for/have more favorable attitudes about Doug Jones than women assigned to the control group. H1c: Women assigned to canvass/phone call are more likely to vote than women assigned to the control group. Cross-pressure hypotheses: H2a. Women assigned to canvass/phone call are less likely to think that Roy Moore is supportive of a women’s role in public life than women assigned to the control group. H2b. Women assigned to canvass/phone call treatment are less likely to vote for/have favorable attitudes of Roy Moore. H2c: Women assigned to canvass/phone call are less likely to vote than women assigned to the control group. Indirect effects (two-tailed tests): Discussion hypotheses: H3a. Women assigned to canvass/phone call are more likely to report speaking to family members about the election than women assigned to the control group. Conflict avoidance hypothesis: H3b. Women assigned to canvass/phone call are less likely to report speaking to family members about the election than women assigned to the control group. Cross-pressure hypotheses: H4a. Men living with women assigned to canvass/phone call are less likely to vote for/have favorable attitudes about Roy Moore than men living with women assigned to the control group. H4b. Men living with women assigned to canvass/phone call are less likely to vote than men living with women assigned to the control group. Counter-mobilization hypotheses: H5a. Men living with women assigned to canvass/phone call are more likely to vote for Roy Moore than men living with women assigned to the control group. H5b. Men living with women assigned to canvass/phone call are more likely to vote than men living with women assigned to the control group.

q17.value: We will test our hypotheses using the unadjusted and covariate-adjusted difference-in-means and difference-in-proportions estimators, and will obtain p-values and confidence intervals using randomization inference. We will use two-tailed tests throughout. All covariate-adjusted estimates will include age, turnout in the 2017 Republican Primary, the 2017 Republican Primary Run-Off Election, the 2016 Republican Presidential Primaries, and the 2016 General Election. The survey outcome variables are vote choice, self-reported turnout, candidate approval, Roy Moore’s perceived support for women’s role in public life, whether the voter has discussed the election with family, and whether she was contacted by the Jones campaign. For the (de)-mobilization hypotheses we will use validated turnout from the public register for both female voters and their spouses.

q23.value: Still undergoing review. The campaign conducts the random assignment and canvassing independently, but agreed to share assignment code and identifiers post-treatment (subject to approval).

attributes.title: Formal and Informal Determinants of Economic Exchange: Conjoint and Survey Experiments

q1.value: Formal and Informal Determinants of Economic Exchange: Conjoint and Survey Experiments

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: This project aims to better understand dimensions of formality and informality among businesses both formal and informal in developing countries. In places where access to rule of law is often a function of a firm’s political connections, how do such considerations affect with whom a firm does business? I explore these dimensions by conducting a survey in Dakar, Senegal amongst a large sample of formal and informal businesses. Within the survey I embed a conjoint experiment and a survey experiment. In the conjoint experiment, respondents choose between two hypothetical deals, with attributes that include informal considerations (e.g., religion, ethnicity, political connections of the firm manager) as well as formal ones (e.g., the type of contract to be used, the size of the other firm). Results will provide evidence for the most important considerations when choosing a business partner, as well as demonstrate how these preferences differ amongst formal and informal firms. The survey experiment will provide evidence on how formal and informal firms differ in their strategies in the case of contract breach when the contract was formal versus informal.

q16.value: Described and enumerated in fuller detail in the pre-analysis plan, the primary hypotheses of the conjoint experiment are that some of the formal and informal attributes may increase (decrease) the likelihood of accepting the deal, and that some of these considerations may increase (decrease) the perception of risk related with the deal, measured as perception of the probability of contract breach. The other primary hypothesis is that these results differ between formal and informal firms. The secondary hypotheses relate to interactions between attributes as well as interactions with respondent characteristics, and are described in the pre-analysis plan. For example, I expect an interactive effect between the type of contract to be used in the deal and the political connections of the firm manager. Subgroups include the formal status of the firm, the wealth and size of the firm, and covariate matches between the respondent and the hypothetical firm manager (e.g., ethnicity, religion, and political connections).

q17.value: There are four categories of estimations: average marginal component effects (AMCEs), average component interaction effects (ACIEs), as well as conditional AMCEs and ACIEs. These will be estimated using the approach described in Hainmueller, Hopkins, and Yamamoto (2014); that is, the linear regression estimator under completely independent randomization. ACIEs, as well as conditional ACMEs and conditional ACIEs, will be estimated with a similar approach albeit with the relevant interaction terms included. Standard errors will be clustered at the respondent level.

attributes.title: Successful and Unsuccessful Vicarious Intergroup Contact

q1.value: Successful and Unsuccessful Vicarious Intergroup Contact

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Intergroup contact is one of the primary methods of prejudice reduction. Many prejudice reduction interventions use television and radio media programs to engage viewers in "vicarious intergroup contact". In vicarious contact, the ingroup member observes another ingroup member interact with an outgroup member. Though the viewer does not directly interact with an outgroup member, the interaction she observes between a fellow ingroup member and the outgroup member provides information to the viewer about what could happen if she interacted with an outgroup member. If the interaction is positive, the viewer should have more positive affect towards the outgroup, similar to direct intergroup contact. Vicarious intergroup contact motivates peacebuilding interventions in violent areas and popular films such as Remember the Titans. It is especially appealing as a prejudice reduction intervention because the quality of the vicarious intergroup contact is controlled. The characters are scripted, so positive contact meeting Allport's four conditions can be ensured: group members interacting (1) cooperatively, for (2) a joint goal, (3) with equal status, and (4) the support of prevailing authorities. However, one potentially vital aspect of intergroup contact has not been explored: the ultimate success or failure of the cooperative contact. Did the cooperation successfully achieve the joint goal, or did the groups fail to achieve their goal? To continue with the example of Remember the Titans, would that intergroup contact have reduced prejudice if the team had lost every game? If contact is only about removing stereotypes, then we might expect that the success or failure of the cooperation will have little to no effect on prejudice reduction. The interaction itself should reshape stereotypes. But if contact is also about a utilitarian expectation of desirable outcomes due to intergroup cooperation, then the success or failure of the cooperation could affect prejudice reduction. A success could lead participants to believe that intergroup cooperation is in their material interest, whereas a failure suggests to them that the groups are better off working alone. This study will expose subjects to vicarious intergroup contact that meets all four of Allport's conditions. One group will see that contact end successfully, and another will see it end unsuccessfully. Everything else about the vicarious contact will remain constant. The groups are Democrats and Republican Trump voters.

q16.value: I hypothesize that successful vicarious contact reduces prejudice more than unsuccessful vicarious contact, and that unsuccessful vicarious contact reduces prejudice relative to no vicarious contact. In this study, I measure several aspects of prejudice: (1) general affect in the form of feelings thermometers and affective polarization questions, (2) threat felt from the other group, (3) stereotypes from the Moral Foundations battery, (4) social distance, (5) infra-humanization, (6) a randomization experiment, and (7) information-seeking about a partisan-aligned interest group. I expect successful vicarious contact will : (1) Increase affect towards out-partisans on the feeling thermometer scale, reduce negative emotions, and increase positive emotions. I also leave in some more neutral emotions for an exploration. Those emotions are envy, guilty, respectful, hurt, proud, and secure. (2) Reduce threat felt from the out-partisans (3) Reduce stereotypes about out-partisans so that treated subjects report smaller differences between Democrats and Republicans (4) Decrease social distance to out-partisans (5) Reduce infra-humanization of out-partisans (in and out-partisans will be assigned more similar traits) (6) More acceptance of joining a group or living in a community with large percentages of out-partisans (7) More information seeking about political groups aligned with the out-party. For each of these hypotheses, I expect the greatest effect for successful vicarious contact. Also, the 7 hypotheses are listed in order of confidence. The final two hypotheses are exploratory and the hypotheses about them are weak. I also measure specific attitudes about the video: (1) relatability of the characters and why, (2) whether or not the characters worked well together and why, (3) whether or not the characters received the grade they deserved, and (4) attitudes about abortion for themselves, Republicans, and Democrats (the characters briefly discuss abortion). (1) - (3) about the video are only asked to people who watched a video. (4) about abortion is asked to everyone. I expect successful vicarious contact will: (1) Increase perceptions that the characters worked together well. I have no expectations about the other questions. They will be used for exploratory analyses. Exploratory analysis: Subjects use Q-sensors to test physiological activation. I weakly expect that physiological activation will moderate the effect of the video. Subjects with high physiological activation will display greater effects than subjects with low physiological activation. I am also interested to see if subjects in the "successful" condition have more or less activation than subjects in the "unsuccessful" condition, but I have no expectations about that. Heterogeneous effects: I expect prejudice reduction to be largest for women in this study, since the video shows two female students working together on a class project. I expect larger effects with higher physiological activation. Validity check: For students who watch the videos, to be sure they received the treatment I ask two informational questions. The first is for general video content and asks what the students in the video worked on. The second is about the success of the students' cooperation and asks the grade they receive for their project. For a robustness check, the analysis will be conducted with all subjects and after removing subjects who failed the validity check.

q17.value: Lab experiment. Subjects randomly assigned to observe (1) successful intergroup contact, (2) unsuccessful intergroup contact, or (3) no video. Between 100 - 120 students in political science classes are the subjects. Subjects come into a lab one at a time in twenty minute blocks to prevent subject interaction. The study itself takes approximately 30 minutes. Subjects enter the lab, sign-in, read and sign a consent form, place the Q-sensor on their non-dominant hand (if watching the video), and begin the study. Subjects are told they are participating in two studies, the first one about a video and the second about groups in the USA. Once the first study is over, subjects are told they will be randomly assigned questions about one of six group pairs: (1) Muslims and Christians (2) African-Americans and Caucasians (3) the rich and the poor (4) voters and non-voters, (5) Democratic people or Republican people (6) rural people and urban people. All subjects are then asked their experimental condition and told that their condition is assigned questions about Democratic people and Republican people. When subjects finish they study they are asked if they have any questions or comments. These are recorded. A full list of questions asked is included in the PAP.

q21.value: A preliminary power analysis was conducted for one of the questions, but a complete power analysis was not conducted.

attributes.title: Citizen Satisfaction, Expectations, and Comparative Performance Information

q1.value: Citizen Satisfaction, Expectations, and Comparative Performance Information

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: We will conduct a survey experiment to study citizen satisfaction with a government service provider (a fictional department of motor vehicles). We will experimentally manipulate two types of comparative performance information: a social reference and a historical reference. We will then measure normative expectations, positive expectations, and satisfaction with single-item survey measures.

q16.value: We intend to test the following hypotheses: 1. The social reference point is positively related to normative expectations. 2. The social reference point is positively related to positive expectations. 3. The historical reference point is positively related to normative expectations. 4. The historical reference point is positively related to positive expectations. 5. Normative expectations are more strongly associated with the social reference point than with the historical reference point. 6. Positive expectations are more strongly associated with the historical reference point than with the social reference point. 7. Normative expectations are negatively related to satisfaction. 8. Satisfaction is more strongly associated with normative expectations than with positive expectations. 9. Positive expectations are associated with satisfaction.

q17.value: We plan to use the following procedures to conduct an initial analysis: We will drop any observations for which there is no valid survey completion code entered into MTurk in order to eliminate the possibility that we have responses from individuals who were not recruited through MTurk. We will drop any observations with foreign IP addresses. If there are multiple observations that have the same IP address, we will drop all observations from those IP addresses to avoid the possibility that one individual completed the survey multiple times. We will drop any observations for which there is no valid response to one or more of the items measuring our three mediating/dependent variables: normative expectations, positive expectations, and satisfaction. We plan to estimate the following regressions in Stata: reg norm_exp soc_ref hist_ref, robust reg pos_exp soc_ref hist_ref, robust reg satisf soc_ref hist_ref, robust reg satisf norm_exp soc_ref hist_ref, robust reg satisf pos_exp soc_ref hist_ref, robust reg satisf norm_exp pos_exp soc_ref hist_ref, robust ivregress 2sls satisf (norm_exp = soc_ref), robust ivregress 2sls satisf (pos_exp = hist_ref), robust ivregress 2sls satisf (norm_exp pos_exp = soc_ref hist_ref), robust

attributes.title: The Argument of Force: The Effectiveness of State Violence in Fighting Against Secessionist Movements

q1.value: The Argument of Force: The Effectiveness of State Violence in Fighting Against Secessionist Movements

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Throughout history, diverse communities have become united and made laws and rules to govern under one government. Other times they chose to stay as separate political entities. Once established, the process of changing borders has generally been uneasy. In fact, separatist conflicts are the main source of violence in today’s world and, of all types of domestic disputes, the ones on self-determination are the most likely to escalate into violence (Walter, 2009). Even though some advanced democratic countries like Canada or the United Kingdom have responded to breakaway demands through either providing policy concessions or holding a self-determination referendum, governments more often resort to state violence in fighting against secessionist movements. This project investigates whether state violence against secessionist movements is effective at appeasing secessionist demands or, by contrast, if state violence backlashes by increasing anger, mistrust toward state institutions, and mobilization against the state in pro-secessionist areas.

q16.value: H1: State violence against secessionism leads to more or less support for secessionist movements H2: State violence against secessionism leads to more or less political participation H3a: If the deterrence effect dominates (less support for secessionist parties and less participation), then people’s emotional reaction to the violent event are likely to be dominated by fear. H3b: If the backlash effect dominates (more support for secessionist parties and more participation), then people’s emotional reaction to the violent events are likely to be dominated by anger. H4: Individuals who had been affected by state violence are less likely to identify with Spain H5: Individuals who had been affected by state violence are less likely to trust Spanish institutions (Spanish police, Spanish government, judicial power, Constitutional Court), but not regional institutions (Catalan police and Catalan government)

q17.value: I propose testing my causal mechanism in two parallel designs, both using evidence from the Spanish state violence against the secessionist movement in Catalonia on October 1st, 2017. First, I have built a dataset with Catalan municipalities as the unit of analysis that includes whether the municipality was affected by state violence on October 1st, 2017; electoral information in prior elections (e.g., turnout and electoral support for the independence in each municipality over time); driving time and distance to the capital of Catalonia, Barcelona, as well as to the province capital; and, municipality-level socioeconomic data such as unemployment, etc. This dataset will be completed with the results of the forthcoming Catalan regional elections on December 21st, 2017 (support for independentist parties and turnout). Second, I will conduct a survey on several towns that had been exposed to state violence during the days leading to the regional elections. In addition, the survey will also be distributed in towns that had not been exposed to state violence but that are otherwise similar across important covariates. A matching algorithm will be employed to pair treated and control towns. The survey will allow me to explore the micro-foundations of the net effects observed in the aggregate relationships.

registration_responses.q1: The Argument of Force: The Effectiveness of State Violence in Fighting Against Secessionist Movements
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities
registration_responses.q15: Throughout history, diverse communities have become united and made laws and rules to govern under one government. Other times they chose to stay as separate political entities. Once established, the process of changing borders has generally been uneasy. In fact, separatist conflicts are the main source of violence in today’s world and, of all types of domestic disputes, the ones on self-determination are the most likely to escalate into violence (Walter, 2009). Even though some advanced democratic countries like Canada or the United Kingdom have responded to breakaway demands through either providing policy concessions or holding a self-determination referendum, governments more often resort to state violence in fighting against secessionist movements. This project investigates whether state violence against secessionist movements is effective at appeasing secessionist demands or, by contrast, if state violence backlashes by increasing anger, mistrust toward state institutions, and mobilization against the state in pro-secessionist areas.
registration_responses.q16: H1: State violence against secessionism leads to more or less support for secessionist movements H2: State violence against secessionism leads to more or less political participation H3a: If the deterrence effect dominates (less support for secessionist parties and less participation), then people’s emotional reaction to the violent event are likely to be dominated by fear. H3b: If the backlash effect dominates (more support for secessionist parties and more participation), then people’s emotional reaction to the violent events are likely to be dominated by anger. H4: Individuals who had been affected by state violence are less likely to identify with Spain H5: Individuals who had been affected by state violence are less likely to trust Spanish institutions (Spanish police, Spanish government, judicial power, Constitutional Court), but not regional institutions (Catalan police and Catalan government)
registration_responses.q17: I propose testing my causal mechanism in two parallel designs, both using evidence from the Spanish state violence against the secessionist movement in Catalonia on October 1st, 2017. First, I have built a dataset with Catalan municipalities as the unit of analysis that includes whether the municipality was affected by state violence on October 1st, 2017; electoral information in prior elections (e.g., turnout and electoral support for the independence in each municipality over time); driving time and distance to the capital of Catalonia, Barcelona, as well as to the province capital; and, municipality-level socioeconomic data such as unemployment, etc. This dataset will be completed with the results of the forthcoming Catalan regional elections on December 21st, 2017 (support for independentist parties and turnout). Second, I will conduct a survey on several towns that had been exposed to state violence during the days leading to the regional elections. In addition, the survey will also be distributed in towns that had not been exposed to state violence but that are otherwise similar across important covariates. A matching algorithm will be employed to pair treated and control towns. The survey will allow me to explore the micro-foundations of the net effects observed in the aggregate relationships.

attributes.title: Unemployment Insurance and Investment in Task-specific Skills: experimental evidence

q1.value: Unemployment Insurance and Investment in Task-specific Skills: experimental evidence

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Does unemployment insurance affect workers’ willingness to make the costly and risky investment in acquiring firm or task-specific skills? This is an exceedingly difficult question to answer with observational data. As yet there is no compelling empirical demonstration of this micro-level policy mechanism. “Skills” are difficult to measure and compare. We conduct a behavioural experiment examining whether unemployment insurance programs affect workers’ willingness to invest in the acquisition of task-specific skills. Experimental sessions will draw from both in-person Oxford-based and online UK labour market populations. These experiments, while stylized, will form the basis for future study in the field.

q16.value: We will test the following hypotheses: 1. The more generous the unemployment scheme the more likely are subjects to invest in skills. We expect the proportion investing when UI is none to be less than the proportion investing when UI is minimal to be less than the proportion investing when UI is generous. 2. Subjects will be less willing to invest in high unemployment compared to low unemployment. 3. The effect of UI generosity on investment proportion will be bigger when unemployment is high compared to when it is low. 4. Subjects will be less likely to wait under high unemployment than under low unemployment. 5. The more generous the unemployment scheme the more likely are subjects to wait, but this effect will only be visible among those who chose to invest. 6. Effort will be unrelated to UI generosity and unemployment.

q17.value: We will randomly assign participants to high/low unemployment settings and generous/minimal/zero unemployment insurance. They will then have the opportunity to acquire a "skill" that makes them more productive at one of the experimental tasks. We evaluate whether subjects choose to invest in the skill and how they react to spells of "unemployment" in the lab. Basic analysis will involve comparing group averages across treatment categories and calculating standard errors around those quantities. We will also employ regression analysis. We will report point estimates, standard errors, and associated p-values under the adjustments described below. We will allow readers to decide whether a particular estimate is “important” but we will present findings with reference to the social science convention of 95% confidence.

attributes.title: Can Historical Learning Generate Belief in Structural Racial Inequality and Reduce Racial Resentment?

q1.value: Can Historical Learning Generate Belief in Structural Racial Inequality and Reduce Racial Resentment?

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Political theorists, historians, and racial justice activists have argued that learning about the historical and structural roots of contemporary racial inequalities (which, for the sake of brevity, we refer to throughout the pre-analysis plan and study as "historical learning") is necessary to perceive contemporary racial inequalities as systemic policy problems that require systemic policy solutions. Despite the ubiquity of this claim across multiple scholarly traditions, the extent to which Americans accept (or reject) historical information when making sense of contemporary racial inequality and how this information affects policy beliefs and attitudes regarding racial inequality are questions that are not well-understood empirically. We have designed a survey experimental test of whether information about the historical and structural roots of present-day inequalities can generate belief in structural racial inequality and reduce racial resentment.

q16.value: There are three main quantities of interest, each of which we estimate separately for Democrats, Independents, and Republicans (i.e., these are all conditional average treatment effects), are: 1. Effect of historical learning on belief in the existence of structural black-white inequality. 2. Effect of historical learning on belief in structural causes of present-day racial inequality. 3. Effect of historical learning on belief in individualistic or cultural causes of present-day racial inequality.

q17.value: We have designed and will field a three-arm experiment using an online survey involving a census-balanced nationally representative sample of subjects recruited using Lucid. For each quantity of interest, we will estimate conditional average treatment effects using OLS and test the null hypothesis that the conditional average treatment effect is equal to zero using a two-sided test. See the attached PAP for additional details.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: A line of research in IR suggests that public dissatisfaction with domestic conditions increases the pressure on leaders to respond with increased firmness in the face of increased international provocation. In the case of China, a long line of historically grounded research points to the importance of perceived passivity in response to provocations or perceived weakness as a magnifier and focal point for domestic dissatisfaction. This survey-experiment tests the behavioral bases of these theories posing two related questions: Does domestic dissatisfaction heighten public demand for aggressive responses to foreign provocation? Do aggressive responses to provocation attenuate dissatisfaction with domestic conditions?

q16.value: This research is sited at the confluence of historical work on the importance of anti-foreign spillovers as determinants of regime support in China and IR research focusing on the public opinion determinants of authoritarian foreign policy. Historians have long argued that the fear of seeming weak has been a key constraint on leaders, including Mao (Yahuda 1978, 45-46), and the behavioral bases for this public opinion effect have been supported by recent experimental work (Dafoe and Chen Weiss 2017). However, the links between domestic instability and the demand for assertive responses is unclear—while it is argued by policy analysts that authoritarian leaders, including China’s, might feel more pressure to show resolve when domestic dissatisfaction is high, there is no research testing this. Similarly, a corollary expectation of this line of argument, that assertive international behavior can lessen the public’s dissatisfaction with domestic issues, remains unexplored. These two unresolved questions motivate the design of this (pilot) survey experiment.

q17.value: There are two main mechanisms of interest: a heightening mechanism and an attenuation mechanism. The heightening mechanism implies that priming respondents’ domestic dissatisfaction heightens their demands for assertiveness and strength in response to international provocation (increases the penalty the government pays for less assertive foreign policy). The attenuation effect implies that the government is rewarded for its strength and assertiveness with higher evaluations of domestic performance. The pilot employs a 2 X 2 factorial design to evaluate the mechanisms of interest.

attributes.title: Do partisan campaigning activities have “downstream effects” on voter turnout at subsequent elections? Evidence from a UK-based partisan GOTV experiment.

q1.value: Do partisan campaigning activities have “downstream effects” on voter turnout at subsequent elections? Evidence from a UK-based partisan GOTV experiment.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This study seeks to examine whether the mobilisation effects in one GOTV field experiment ‘spill over’ to another election. I conducted a partisan GOTV experiment during the May 2017 local elections in the UK (“election 1”), and found that leaflets and canvass visits boost turnout. In this analysis, I seek to test whether exposure to these treatments had "downstream" effects and also boosted turnout at the general election the following month (“election 2"). In addition, I seek to assess whether this effect differs according to a pre-existing covariate measuring whether voters are registered to vote by post, or in-person. As far as I am aware, this experiment represents one of the few temporal spillover partisan field experiments conducted in the UK.

q16.value: I found that partisan campaign treatment boosted turnout at election 1 by 3.7 percentage points (ITT, covariate-adjusted). The purpose of this study is to analyse whether – and how much – of these effects ‘spilled over’ to the general election the following month (“election 2”). I anticipate that the downstream effect at election 2 will be around half of the original effects at election 1. As such, I expect that exposure to partisan campaign activities at election 1 will increase voter turnout at election 2 by around 1.8 percentage points (H1). I also anticipate that the spillover effect of the treatment will be higher among non-postal voters. supporters of that party (H2).

q17.value: I will test my hypotheses using the same estimator that was used to analyse the turnout effects in Election 1. I used a multivariate linear regression of turnout on assigned treatment, and controlled for covariates that were available from the local party voter database (sex, party support (based on previous canvass analysis), ward, postal voter registration, previous turnout, whether the individual lives in a single occupancy household, and age group). The same covariate-adjusted regression model will be run with turnout at election 2 as the dependent variable, rather than turnout at election 1.

In addition, I seek to assess whether this effect differs according to a pre-existing covariate measuring whether voters are registered to vote by post, or in-person. As far as I am aware, this experiment represents one of the few temporal spillover partisan field experiments conducted in the UK.

The same covariate-adjusted regression model will be run with turnout at election 2 as the dependent variable, rather than turnout at election 1.

attributes.title: Who Runs, Who Communicates and Who Votes: An Experiment in Effective Political Communication

q1.value: Who Runs, Who Communicates and Who Votes: An Experiment in Effective Political Communication

q5.value: Skidmore College Department of Political Science, Skidmore College Summer Collaborative Research Program, Professor Sandra Goff, Henry Jaffe, Kathleen Searles, Stephen Ansolabehere, and Brian Schaffner

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: The American public is bombarded with political communication from various sources with varying information. Do voters trust one source over others when hearing about politics? What sources are the most convincing? And does gender matter? Scholars have separately examined different sources of political communication, but rarely directly compared the effect of different sources. We conducted a survey experiment embedded in the 2016 Cooperative Congressional Election Study measuring the effectiveness of the same message across sources, using a peer-to-peer message, a political advertisement, and a political reporter as the possible sources. We report the effect of the source on respondents’ perceptions of candidates’ likeability, ethics, and openness. We then examine how the effectiveness changed in relation to the gender of the source and the gender of the candidate described in the vignette.

q16.value: H1: When a messenger reports about specific traits of a candidate, voters will connect those traits with the candidates more or less strongly depending on the type of messenger. (two-tailed) H2: When a respondent is presented with information about a specific trait in a candidate, he or she will later identify that candidate as having high levels of the trait more than other traits. (one-tailed) H3: A source may convey one trait more effectively than other traits (two-tailed) H3.1: A source may convey a trait more effectively than other sources (two-tailed) H4: When information about a candidate trait is delivered by a female reporter or female neighbor, it will be less effective than when a male reporter or neighbor delivers the message. (one-tailed) H4.1: When information about a candidate being experienced is delivered, the gender gap in effective communication measures will be greater than when describing likeability and ethicality. (one-tailed) H5: Respondents will perceive candidate’s traits differently based on the gender of the candidate. (two-tailed) H5.1: Respondents will consider a female candidate to be more “trustworthy” and “ethical” than a male candidate. (one-tailed) H5.2: Respondents will consider a female candidate more “likable” than a male candidate. (one-tailed) H5.3: Female candidates will be more likely to score high on likeability measures when they are described using the “experience” vignette. (one-tailed) H6: Female respondents will rate traits differently than male respondents. (two-tailed) H6.1: Female respondents will rate traits differently than men for each type of messenger. (two-tailed) H6.2: Female respondents will rate traits communicated by a female messenger differently than male respondents. (two-tailed) H6.3: Female respondents will rate traits differently than male respondents based on the gender of the candidate. (two-tailed) H6.4: Female respondents will rate a female candidate as more highly “experienced” than a male respondent will. (one-tailed)

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested using a series of regression analyses, measuring the average treatment effects of the experimental treatments and the conditional average treatment effects of gender. I will be using Stata to conduct these hypotheses. The variables will be dummy variables, ordinal variables from the Likert scale in the experimental outcome variable, and a dichotomous variable for high values within the Likert scale.

q27.value: Cooperative Congressional Election Survey. Conducted using tools by Yougov.com
